{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2997742,"name":"Peyton Yeung","username":"Peyton_Yeung","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peyton_yeung/{size}/4840_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-25T03:26:26.656Z","cooked":"

Today we tested a tread jig for our 4" AndyMark performance wheels. The left jig allows us to mark/cut the 1" wide tread to length as well as drill the rivet holes. The right jig allows us to clock the wheel to the right orientation using the bolt circle (only ended up needing 2 of the holes) and drill the mounting holes in the rim of the wheel.

The holes in the 3d printed jigs were sized and tapped for 1/4-20 bolts which were bored to 1/8" on the lathe (aka DIY cheap drill bushings).

Over all we’re pretty happy with how they turned out and it should allow us to make consistent tread replacements.

IMG_20220124_2033346354000×3000 4.11 MB

I wonder what drill bit fits the hollow cap head screws to save that step.
